q: What is the primary goal of the 'Business Understanding' phase in a data science project?
o: To understand the business objectives and requirements
To clean and preprocess the data
To build and train machine learning models

q: Which of the following best describes 'Problem Definition' in data science?
o: Translating a business question into a clear, actionable data science problem
Collecting raw data from various sources
Choosing the best algorithm for modeling

q: Success metrics should ideally be ______ and aligned with business goals.
Who are considered stakeholders in a data science project?
o: Anyone affected by or who can affect the project outcome
Only the data scientists working on the model

q: In the Business Understanding phase, it is important to identify ______ early to avoid project failure.
A well-defined data science problem is usually framed as a ______ that can be answered with data.
Which of the following is NOT typically part of defining success metrics?
o: Choosing the color scheme for dashboards

q: Effective stakeholder management involves regular ______ to keep everyone aligned.
Match the following terms with their correct descriptions:
right: Understanding objectives and requirements from a business perspective
Clearly stating the data science question to be solved
Quantitative measures to evaluate project success
Identifying and engaging people who have interest in the project

q: A regression problem with the goal of predicting house prices should primarily optimize for business value rather than just model accuracy.
It is acceptable to proceed with modeling without clearly defined success metrics if the data is very clean.
Rearrange the steps to form the correct logical flow of Problem Formulation:
Which of the following is an example of a good success metric for a churn prediction model?
o: Increase in customer retention rate by 10%
Model achieves 99% accuracy on training data
The model uses a Random Forest algorithm

q: Failing to involve the right stakeholders early can lead to ______ at the end of the project.
o: The model not being used or trusted

q: The phrase 'We want to reduce customer complaints' is an example of a ______ rather than a well-defined data science problem.
Which framework explicitly includes 'Business Understanding' as its first phase?
A vague request like 'Do something with our sales data' should first be converted into a ______.
Success metrics can be divided into ______ metrics (e.g., accuracy) and ______ metrics (e.g., revenue uplift).
Match the stakeholder role with its typical primary concern:
right: Project ROI and strategic alignment
Data pipeline reliability and latency
Usability and interpretability of the solution
Regulatory risk and ethical implications

q: Defining the problem as 'Build a machine learning model' instead of focusing on the business outcome is known as ______.
A good success metric must satisfy the SMART criteria.
It is fine to have success metrics that only the data science team understands.
Rearrange these activities into the recommended order during Problem Formulation:
words: Translate objectives into data science questions
Define primary and secondary success metrics

q: In a fraud detection project, using only AUC-ROC as the success metric without considering the cost of false positives is usually ______.
o: Acceptable if the model is deployed in production

q: The 'XY Problem' in data science projects refers to ______.
o: Stakeholders asking for a specific solution (Y) instead of stating the actual problem (X)
Asking for two different models at once
Confusion between X-train and y-train variables

q: Primary stakeholders usually include the person who ______ the project and the person who ______ the solution daily.
What is the output of this code?
c:
print("Key Question".center(40, "="))
print("How much revenue will we lose if we don't act on churn in the next 6 months?")
print("="*40)
o: A well-framed business question ready for data science translation
A technical specification for model training

q: Stakeholder management is a one-time activity that should be completed during the kick-off meeting.
For a recommendation system, 'Increase click-through rate by 15%' is generally a better success metric than 'Achieve NDCG@10 > 0.85' because ______.
o: It is directly tied to business impact and understandable by non-technical stakeholders
NDCG is not a valid metric
CTR is always easier to compute

q: Which of the following questions helps most in moving from business need to problem definition?
o: "What decision will be made differently if we have this answer?"
"Which algorithm performs best on this dataset?"
"How much data do we currently have?"

q: A retail chain says: 'We lose too many customers.' A strong translation into a data science problem would be:
o: Predict which customers are likely to churn in the next 30 days so marketing can intervene
Build a clustering model with 8 clusters
Create a daily report of all canceled orders
Train a deep learning model on transaction data

q: The 'Five Whys' technique is most useful during which part of problem formulation?
o: Uncovering the root business problem behind surface symptoms

q: A project will be considered successful if customer lifetime value increases by at least ______% within ______ months of model deployment.
Match these poorly framed requests to their improved data-science-ready versions:
right: Forecast daily sales per store for the next 14 days to optimize staffing and inventory
Implement a demand forecasting model that reduces stock-outs by at least 30%
Build a customer segmentation that identifies high-value but at-risk accounts for proactive retention
Develop a pricing recommendation engine that maximizes margin while keeping market share loss under 2%

q: Rearranging the following sentence creates a classic warning sign of poor problem formulation:
Involving the legal team only at the deployment stage instead of during problem formulation is an example of ignoring ______ stakeholders.
What is the output of this code?
c:
problem = "Improve NPS score"
solution = "sentiment analysis on survey comments"
print(f"Direct jump from {problem} to {solution} without quantifying impact")
print("Risk: High" if "quantifying" not in locals() else "Risk: Low")

q: A data science team should refuse a project when no stakeholder can clearly state the action that will change based on the model’s output.
The term 'north star metric' in problem formulation refers to ______.
o: The single most important business metric the project must move
The metric with the highest statistical significance
The metric that is easiest to compute
The metric preferred by senior leadership regardless of relevance

q: During stakeholder interviews, asking 'What would perfect look like?' helps define ______.
o: The ideal success criteria and aspirational metrics

q: Success metrics defined only in terms of model performance (e.g., F1-score ≥ 0.92) without any link to business impact are called ______ metrics.
An effective project charter created during problem formulation should explicitly contain ______.
o: All four: business objective, data science question, primary success metric, and key stakeholders
Only the list of datasets to be used
The names of algorithms that will be tested
A Gantt chart with exact delivery dates

q: Stakeholders who are high in power but low in interest should typically receive which communication strategy?
Turning 'Reduce operational costs' into 'Predict equipment failure 7+ days in advance to enable preventive maintenance' is an example of moving from ______ to ______.
It is acceptable to change the primary success metric after the modeling phase has started if new insights emerge.
A hospital administrator says: 'We have too many readmissions.' The strongest data science problem formulation would focus on:
o: Predicting 30-day readmission risk at discharge to trigger targeted post-care interventions
Building a real-time dashboard of current inpatients
Training a GAN on historical EHR data

q: The main purpose of a 'Decision-Making Impact Map' during problem formulation is to:
o: Show exactly which business decision will change based on model predictions and its expected financial effect
List all tables in the data warehouse

q: In a pricing optimization project, the success metric 'increase total margin dollars by $______ within ______ quarters' is better than a percentage because large customers dominate revenue.
Match these real-world business pains to the most appropriate data science framing:
left: Field technicians are idle half the day
right: Predictive routing + skill-based matching to reduce average handle time by 20%
Multi-touch attribution model to reallocate $40M media budget
Demand + shelf-life forecasting to reduce waste below 3%
Dynamic scheduling + travel-time prediction to increase jobs per tech from 4.2 to 6+

q: Rearrange these stakeholder quotes to reveal a classic scope-creep pattern:
What is the output of this code?
c:
objective = "Detect defects on production line"
metric = "99.9% detection rate"
context = "Each missed defect costs $50k in recalls"
print("Well formulated" if "$" in context else "Missing business context")

q: Asking 'What is the cost of doing nothing?' during stakeholder interviews is powerful because it quantifies:
o: The baseline economic impact of the current problem (the value at stake)

q: A success metric that improves while the actual business outcome worsens is called a ______ metric.
Defining the problem as a 'classification task with imbalanced classes' instead of starting from the business process is an example of:
The 'So What?' test applied repeatedly during problem formulation helps separate:
o: Actionable insights from merely interesting findings

q: Stakeholders who oppose the project but have high power are called ______ in a power-interest grid.
o: Blockers (manage closely and convert if possible)

q: A well-written data science question must always be answerable with ______ and drive a ______.
It is normal and expected that the initial success metric agreed in week 1 will remain unchanged throughout the entire project.
The single most common reason sophisticated ML models never get used in production is:
o: Poor problem formulation and lack of clear actionability
Using XGBoost instead of neural networks

q: When a stakeholder says 'accuracy is what matters most,' the best clarifying question is:
o: 'What is the business cost of a false positive vs. a false negative?'

q: The 'Problem Boundary Diagram' is a tool used during problem formulation to visually separate:
o: What is in scope, out of scope, and controllable vs. uncontrollable

q: A credit-risk team initially defined success as 'AUC > 0.85'. After discussion they changed it to 'Reduce default losses by at least $______M per year at fixed approval rate'. This change reflects moving from a ______ metric to a ______ metric.
Match these anti-patterns to their common names in data science projects:
left: Starting modeling before anyone can explain the required action
Changing the target definition three times after baseline
Defining success only by p-values and R-squared
Building a perfect model no one is allowed to use because of compliance
right: Solution without a problem
Moving target syndrome
Statistical significance ≠ business significance
Ivory-tower ML / last-mile failure

q: Rearrange these sentences to form the ideal one-sentence project objective used by top consulting firms:
What is the output of this code?
The 'Action–Prediction–Decision' triangle must always be completed in that exact order during problem formulation.
A pharmaceutical company wants to 'shorten clinical trials'. The most actionable data science translation is:
o: Predict which patients are most likely to respond to treatment to enrich trial enrollment and reduce required sample size by 25%
Cluster all past trial participants using t-SNE
Build a generative model to create synthetic patients
Create a daily KPI dashboard for trial sites

q: Asking 'If this model is 100% accurate tomorrow, what exactly do you do differently on Monday?' is known as the ______ test.
In a supply-chain optimization project, the north-star metric was initially '99% forecast accuracy'. After realizing overstock and understock have very different costs, they correctly switched to:
o: Minimizing asymmetric cost function (weighted inventory holding + stockout penalty)

q: Stakeholder alignment is officially complete when:
o: Every key stakeholder has signed the one-page Problem Definition Document

q: The 'Value–Effort Matrix' used in early project scoping places problems into four quadrants. The quadrant labeled 'Quick Wins' contains problems that are ______ value and ______ effort.
Defining the problem as 'We need computer vision' instead of 'Reduce false rejects on the assembly line from 8% to under 1%' is called:
A project without a defined 'owner of the metric' (the person whose bonus depends on it moving) has a high risk of becoming a science project rather than a business project.
The best time to discover that the required ground-truth label does not exist in any system is:
o: During the first week of business understanding (before any modeling starts)
When presenting final results to executives

q: Which of these is NOT a mandatory section in a strong Data Science Project Charter?
o: List of planned Python packages and versions

q: A bank says: 'Too many loan applications are manually reviewed.' The most precise data science problem statement is:
o: Develop an automated pre-scoring model that safely straight-through-processes at least 40% of applications while keeping additional bad debt below 0.2% of portfolio
Build a neural network with 12 hidden layers on application data
Create a real-time dashboard of pending applications

q: The 'Eisenhower Matrix' adapted for data science projects helps decide whether a requested analysis is:
o: Urgent & Important, Important but not Urgent, Urgent but not Important, or Neither

q: We will consider the customer-segmentation project successful when marketing can increase campaign response rate from ______% to at least ______% using the new segments.
Match these famous failed data science projects to their root problem-formulation mistake:
right: Over-reliance on search-query proxy that drifted over time
No clear clinical decision workflow integration and evidence hierarchy mismatch
Success measured only by MAE instead of actual business usage and trust
No stakeholder alignment on safety boundaries and real-time moderation

q: Rearrange these whispered hallway comments into a red-flag phrase every data scientist dreads hearing after month 3:
What is the output of this code?
c:
scope = "global optimization of pricing across 47 countries"
data_availability = "only reliable for 4 countries"
print("Project status:" if scope.split()[3] == data_availability.split()[-2] else "Immediate re-scoping required")

q: The 'Golden Circle' framework (Why → How → What) applied to data science projects recommends starting every kickoff with the ______ first.
o: Why (the business reason this project exists)

q: When a stakeholder insists 'We just need 95% accuracy,' the most powerful counter-question is:
o: 'At what cost? How much are you willing to pay per additional correct prediction?'
'Do you want it monthly or weekly?'

q: The term 'surrogate metric' is most accurately used when the real business KPI is too ______ or too ______ to measure directly.
A project that can only move a metric already trending upward by 0.3% with 6 months of effort is best classified as:
The 'RACI matrix' during problem formulation clarifies who is ______ for the success metric moving.
Defining success as 'deliver a model with recall > 0.8' instead of 'reduce financial fraud losses by > $4M/year' violates the principle of:
It is perfectly acceptable to have multiple north-star metrics as long as they are all tracked in the same dashboard.
The single most important sentence to write (and get signed off) during problem formulation is the:
o: One-sentence success criterion that links model output to business impact
List of all data sources and owners

q: An insurance company discovers during week 2 that the label 'fraud' is only applied after a 180-day investigation. This discovery invalidates the original problem formulation because:
o: The ground truth is not available at prediction time → label leakage risk and impossible real-world deployment
180 days is too long for training

q: The 'Jobs to Be Done' framework helps reframe a stakeholder's request from a desired solution to:
o: The underlying job the customer or business is trying to get done
The technical job of training a model
The job of cleaning data faster
The job of presenting results in PowerPoint

q: A logistics company wants 'fewer delayed shipments'. A measurable success metric that survives the 'So What?' test would be 'reduce on-time delivery from ______% to ______% resulting in $______M retained revenue'.
Match these project nicknames commonly heard in industry to their actual problem-formulation failure:
right: Amazing model, zero business adoption
Endlessly expanding scope with no clear success definition
Keeps getting funded despite missing every metric
Stitched together from five previous failed attempts with conflicting objectives

q: Rearrange these fragments into the golden question every data scientist must ask before writing a single line of code:
What is the output of this code?

The 'Pre-Mortem' exercise conducted during problem formulation assumes the project has failed and asks 'Why?' in order to:
o: Surface hidden risks and misaligned expectations early

q: When a VP says 'I need predictive analytics', the most effective response is to ask:
o: 'What would you do differently next week if a prediction was available?'
'How many terabytes of data do you have?'

q: The 'Cialdini Commitment & Consistency' principle can be used in stakeholder management by getting written sign-off on the success metric ______ the modeling begins.
An e-commerce company measures success of its search engine by 'increase revenue per visitor by ______% while keeping abandonment rate under ______%'. This is an example of a balanced metric pair.
The phrase 'We will know we have won when...' must be completed with a sentence that contains a number, a time frame, and a person responsible.

o: Weighted probability forecasting + incentive-aligned calibration metric
Using only closed-won deals as labels

q: The 'KANO model' adapted to data science helps distinguish between basic expectations, performance features, and:
o: Delighters (unexpected capabilities that create disproportionate value)

q: A strong problem formulation document is typically no longer than ______ page(s) and fits on one slide when presented to executives.

o: High-impact + high-feasibility opportunities that should be prioritized
Ideas with the most data already available
Requests coming from the highest-paid executives

q: A telecom company defines success as 'increase average revenue per user (ARPU) by at least ______ within ______ months of launching personalized bundle recommendations'.
Match these classic stakeholder archetypes to their typical behavior during problem formulation:
right: Loves big ideas but never commits to measurable outcomes
Questions everything and demands proof the problem even exists
Agrees in meetings but is never available for follow-up
Wants to approve every feature column and hyperparameter

q: Rearrange these words to form the single most dangerous sentence a stakeholder can say in week 8 of a project:
What is the output of this code?
o: Impossible without proxy labels or survival modeling

q: Using 'model deployed to production' as the primary success metric instead of actual business value change is known as measuring output instead of outcome.
The 'Four Disciplines of Execution' framework recommends that every data science project must have exactly one:
o: Wildly Important Goal (WIG) with a from-X-to-Y-by-when format
Lead measure and one lag measure
Weekly cadence meeting and a scoreboard
All of the above (but only one WIG)

q: When translating 'improve employee satisfaction' into a data science problem, the strongest version includes predicting ______ to enable ______.
o: voluntary turnover 60–120 days in advance / proactive retention offers that reduce regrettable attrition by 25%
daily mood from Slack messages / sending automated wellness emails
office temperature preferences / adjusting HVAC automatically

q: The 'Parking Lot' technique during kickoff workshops is used to:
o: Capture good ideas that are explicitly out of scope to prevent future scope creep

q: A manufacturing client will declare the defect-detection project a success only when annual scrap cost drops from $______M to below $______M.
The 'MECE' principle (Mutually Exclusive, Collectively Exhaustive) is most valuable when:
o: Breaking down a vague business problem into non-overlapping, comprehensive sub-problems

q: An energy trader requests 'better price forecasts'. The correct next question is:
o: 'How many basis points of PnL would a 1% improvement in forecast accuracy generate?'

q: Success metrics that are perfectly measurable but do not actually move the business needle are called vanity metrics.

A project whose value proposition disappears the moment a simple rule-based baseline is implemented should:
o: Be celebrated as a quick win and closed immediately
Continue with ML anyway for learning purposes
Be hidden to protect team morale

q: The 'Lightning Decision Jam' format is increasingly used in data science kickoffs because it forces a room of stakeholders to agree on the single most important problem in under 90 minutes.
A fashion retailer wants 'less dead inventory'. The sharpest success metric is 'reduce end-of-season markdown value from ______% to ______% of original retail price'.
Match these red-flag phrases (often said with a smile) to what they actually predict about project success:
left: We'll figure out the metrics later
right: Almost certain failure or massive re-scoping
No budget or timeline pressure → endless drift
No identified owner or integration plan
Classic fishing expedition with no hypothesis

q: Rearrange these words into the question that instantly separates real business problems from fake ones:

print("Priority level:", "Moonshot" if risk == "No one loses their job if this project fails" else "Must-win")

q: The 'Theory of Change' canvas requires you to map backward from desired long-term outcome all the way to the exact prediction the model must make.
When a stakeholder says 'We tried this five years ago and it didn’t work,' the best response is:
o: 'What was the exact success metric then, and what would be considered success today?'

q: A city government wants 'fairer resource allocation'. A concrete, defensible formulation is:
o: Predict which 311 complaints will escalate to emergencies within 72h to pre-deploy crews and reduce response time disparity across neighborhoods by >40%
Cluster all complaints using BERT embeddings
Build a public dashboard with heatmaps
Train a model on 10 years of call logs

o: False – it is a Gartner method

In a demand-sensing project for consumer goods, the team switched from 'improve forecast accuracy' to 'reduce safety stock by $______M while keeping service level above ______%'. This is an example of moving from a technical to an economic metric.
The 'Bus Factor' for a data science project should ideally be greater than 1 before the end of the problem-formulation phase (meaning at least two people fully understand the business context).

A startup founder says 'We need growth hacking with AI'. The translation that survived three board reviews was:
o: Predict 7-day LTV at signup with <20% MAPE to stop acquiring users with predicted LTV < CAC
Add a chatbot to the landing page

q: The phrase 'We don’t need a success metric, we’ll know it when we see it' is universally recognized as:
o: A project-killer that should trigger immediate escalation or termination

q: Which of the following is the most common reason a data science project is declared 'successful' by the team but considered a failure by the business sponsor?
o: Success was defined using model-centric metrics instead of business-centric metrics
The model was deployed using Flask instead of FastAPI
The team used 75/25 train-test split instead of 80/20
Feature importance was shown using permutation instead of SHAP

right: Continuously discover opportunities by asking 'How could we...?'
One-page canvas with 9 blocks including assumptions, constraints, and risks

Choose one metric that, if improved, makes everything else easier or unnecessary

q: Success metrics should always include a 'floor' (minimum acceptable improvement) and a 'moonshot' target to align expectations.

The 'Current-State vs Desired-State Gap Analysis' is most useful for turning vague complaints into quantifiable problems.
When a stakeholder says 'We need more insights', the most effective reframing question is:

Quick 2×2 prioritization used in design sprints

q: Rearrange these elements into the exact sequence of the 'Mission Briefing' format used by McKinsey for data science projects:
What is the output of this code?
o: Stop – go measure current process first

q: The 'Anti-Problem' technique asks: 'What would have to be true for this problem to not be worth solving?' This helps uncover hidden assumptions.
The 'Future Press Release' exercise, popularized by Amazon, forces the team to write a fictional press release dated ______ months in the future announcing the project's success.
Stakeholders who control the data but are not the end users are known as:
o: Gatekeepers – they must be converted into active supporters early
Data owners – can be ignored after extraction

Written record of every agreed decision to prevent 'I never said that'

q: Rearrange these sentences into the exact wording of the 'Prussian General Staff' question used by elite strategy teams:
What is the output of this code?

q: The 'Regret Minimization Framework' applied to project selection means choosing the problem where future-you would most regret NOT having solved it.

o: Problem owner • Current pain cost • Desired future state • Success metric + target + date • Decision owner

Team members • Tools • Budget • Timeline • Risks
Executive summary • Methodology • Results • Next steps • Appendix

q: The 'Counterfactual Question' technique asks stakeholders:
o: 'If we built nothing at all, what would actually happen to the business in the next 12 months?'
'Who should be on the steering committee?'

q: A success metric expressed as 'improve customer satisfaction' fails the 'Dead Man Test' because even a dead man can achieve it by doing nothing.

q: The 'Success Slider' technique asks stakeholders to place a slider between ______ and ______ to force explicit discussion of minimum viable success vs. stretch goals.

left: Who gets fired if this doesn’t move?

right: Reveals true accountability and urgency

q: Rearrange these words into the famous 'Bank of England' question used to kill 90% of proposed projects:
What is the output of this code?
The 'Kill/Marry/Date' game played with sticky notes forces executives to explicitly decide which problems to stop, fully commit to, or only explore lightly.

When a stakeholder claims 'This will pay for itself', the only acceptable response is to ask for the exact ______ they have already calculated.

The 'Decision X-Ray' template forces the team to answer: Decision maker = ______, Decision frequency = ______, Decision latency tolerated = ______, Economic value per correct decision = ______.
The 'Ghost Card' technique during workshops allows anonymous submission of concerns (e.g., 'This metric is gamed every quarter-end') to surface politically sensitive blockers.
A well-formulated data science problem must pass the 'Grandma Test': a non-technical person (like your grandma) should be able to understand why the company is spending money on it.
The 'Scope Hammer' is the moment when the facilitator literally draws a hard line on the whiteboard and declares everything to the right as 'future phase 2' to prevent endless expansion.
o: A real facilitation technique used by experienced consultants
A hardware tool for server installation
A Python library for boundary detection

q: The 'Value Waterfall' visualization shows how much money is lost at each step of the current process, instantly revealing the single biggest lever for a predictive model.
The 'Ladder of Abstraction' exercise is used during problem formulation to move fluidly between high-level business goals and concrete data science tasks without getting stuck at either extreme.
A call-center director complains about 'agent burnout'. The strongest actionable translation is:
o: Predict next-month voluntary attrition risk per agent with >78% recall on high-risk group so HR can proactively offer retention bonuses and reduce turnover cost by ≥$1.8M annually
Run sentiment analysis on recorded calls
Cluster agents by handle time and CSAT

q: The 'Four-Box Trade-Off Slider' forces stakeholders to explicitly rank ______, ______, ______, and ______ when they claim everything is top priority.
Match these ultra-specific red flags to their almost certain project outcome:
left: Success metric owner is a committee
First workshop ends with 'Let’s see what the data tells us'
No one can name the current manual process owner
right: Metric will never move – accountability diffused
Project will be deprioritized the moment budget gets tight
Fishing expedition → 4 months later still exploring
Model will sit unused because no one feels ownership to integrate

q: Rearrange these words into the brutally honest question top VCs ask founders (and you should ask sponsors):
What is the output of this code?
The 'Russian Doll' scoping method starts with the tiniest possible problem that still delivers real money, then adds layers only if the smaller doll already works.
The 'Zombie Metric' is a KPI that everyone still tracks but no one has looked at or acted on in over a year.
The 'Magic Wand' question ('If you had a perfect model tomorrow, what is the very first thing you would do differently on Monday?') is designed to reveal the exact point of decision leverage.
o: False – it’s only for executive presentations

q: The 'Bet Sizing' framework from poker applied to data science portfolios says you should only run projects where the expected value is at least ______ times the cost.
The 'Reverse Dependency Map' starts from the CEO’s top 3 priorities and traces backward to see if your project actually touches any of them.
A project that survives the 'Delete Key Test' (if someone accidentally deleted the entire codebase, would anyone ask to rebuild it?) is almost certainly solving a real problem.
The 'Silent Reading Rule' in final sign-off meetings requires every attendee to silently read the one-page problem definition for 3 minutes before anyone is allowed to speak.
o: True – prevents senior hippo (highest-paid person’s opinion) from dominating

q: The 'Pain-to-Paper Ratio' is a real (tongue-in-cheek) metric: if the documented pain description is shorter than the proposed solution architecture diagram, the project is probably solution-driven.
The single most underused artifact in enterprise data science is the signed 'Success Contract' that lists the exact date, metric target, and names of people whose bonuses depend on it.
The 'Event Storming' workshop technique, borrowed from Domain-Driven Design, is exceptionally good at uncovering hidden business rules and decision points that should become prediction targets.
Which of the following is the strongest leading indicator that a data science project will fail during the first 3 weeks of problem formulation?
o: No stakeholder can provide the current baseline value of the proposed success metric
The team has not yet chosen between XGBoost and LightGBM
The dataset is stored in CSV instead of Parquet
Jupyter notebooks are not yet shared on GitHub

q: The 'Impact Ladder' has five rungs from bottom to top: Data → ______ → Insight → Action → Outcome.
Match these rare but deadly problem formulation anti-patterns to their nicknames:
right: Highest-paid person defines the problem without data or ownership
Everyone complains but no one actually owns or feels the pain
Exciting problem in a business unit the team doesn’t understand and will never implement
Copying another company’s project because 'they did it' without local context

q: Rearrange these words into the question that instantly kills 70% of requested 'dashboards disguised as data science projects':
What is the output of this code?
The 'Mom Test' rule states that you should never ask stakeholders what they want; instead ask about their ______ behavior.
The 'Prediction–Decision–Value' chain must be documented in that exact order and signed by the decision owner before any modeling begins.
The 'Constraint Clinic' is a 60-minute workshop dedicated solely to listing every real or imagined constraint (budget, legal, technical, political) so they stop being used as silent blockers.
The 'No Metric, No Meeting' rule means any workshop invitation that does not include a proposed measurable outcome is automatically declined.
The 'Business Time vs Clock Time' trap occurs when a process that runs monthly is mistakenly treated as if daily predictions are needed.
The 'Five Whys + One How' extension asks not only the five whys to find root cause, but then one final 'How do we measure that this root cause has improved?'.
The 'Decision Inventory' exercise requires listing every decision in the business process and tagging each as 'Human', 'Rule-based', or 'Model-eligible' within 2 hours.

qbtn: Which of these is considered the ultimate stress-test for a well-formulated data science problem?
o: Can a smart intern explain it to a new hire in under 2 minutes without using the words 'AI' or 'machine learning'?
Does it fit on a single PowerPoint slide with font size 18+?
Has it been approved by the architecture review board?
Does it mention at least three different algorithms?

q: The 'Painstorming' session (opposite of brainstorming) is dedicated exclusively to listing everything that currently hurts about the process before any solutions are allowed.
The 'Silent Workshop Starter' rule bans talking for the first 15 minutes of a problem formulation session so everyone individually writes pain points on sticky notes first.
Which of these is the most dangerous hidden stakeholder in almost every enterprise data science project?
o: The middle manager whose team size shrinks if the model succeeds
The external consultant who wrote the legacy rules
The intern who labeled the original training data
The vendor who sells the current reporting tool

q: The 'Metric Tree' diagram branches from a single north-star metric backward through ______ metrics, ______ metrics, and finally input drivers.
Match these almost-never-taught but lethal scoping traps to their official names:
right: First metric anyone mentions becomes impossible to change later
Keeping a failing project alive because 'we already spent six months exploring'
No single business person willing to stand up in public and own the outcome
Real but unspoken success criterion (e.g., 'make my boss look good') that trumps everything

q: Rearrange these words into the question that separates real urgency from fake urgency in 3 seconds:
What is the output of this code?
o: Model must run mid-week – batch job on Monday won’t work

q: The 'Kill the Winner' game is a counter-intuitive prioritization method where the team deliberately tries to poke holes in the apparently strongest project idea to see if it survives.
The 'Data Availability Chicken' game is played when stakeholders promise data exists, but no one has actually checked until the modeling phase begins.
The 'One Throat to Choke' principle insists that exactly ______ person must be accountable for the business metric moving, not the model accuracy.

The 'Prediction Latency Budget' calculation subtracts data pipeline delay + model inference time + decision notification delay from the total time between prediction opportunity and last moment to act.
The 'Ghost of Projects Past' exercise reviews the last three failed data science initiatives in the company to extract the exact formulation mistake that killed each one.
The 'Minimum Detectable Effect' (MDE) must be calculated during problem formulation, not after modeling, to confirm the company can actually notice the improvement you promise.
Which of these is considered the nuclear weapon of stakeholder alignment?
o: Getting the CFO to publicly state the exact dollar value of the project in a town hall
Creating a 40-slide deck with animated transitions
Adding the project to the CEO’s OKR dashboard

q: The 'Scope Creep Speedometer' is a real-time counter on the wall that increases by $50k every time someone says 'Can’t we also just...?' during scoping workshops.

The 'Law of Shitty First Drafts' applied to problem formulation says the first written version of the success metric will always be terrible and must be rewritten at least ______ times with stakeholders.
The 'Prediction → Action → Value' triad is considered broken when the arrow from prediction to action is missing or hypothetical.
Which of these is the real reason 60–80% of data science projects never cross the pilot stage, according to Gartner and McKinsey?
o: No clear operational owner willing to change a process based on the model output

q: The 'Value Per Prediction Clock' starts ticking the moment the prediction is generated and stops when the ______ is taken. Any project with >48-hour average latency is usually dead on arrival.
Match these brutal but effective project-killing questions to their typical use:
left: Who loses headcount if this succeeds?
What happens if we simply copy last year’s plan?
Who is writing the integration code?
How many people will see this prediction before it’s too late to act?
right: Reveals hidden saboteurs
Exposes lack of real urgency
Tests existence of deployment path
Uncovers operational latency bombs

q: Rearrange these words into the single sentence that instantly ends 90% of 'exploratory' project requests:
What is the output of this code?
o: Not worth automating – humans are cheap enough

q: The 'Two-Pizza Rule' for problem formulation meetings states that if more than two pizzas are needed to feed everyone in the room, the problem is not yet well-defined.
The 'Last Responsible Moment' principle says you should delay locking the success metric until the last moment when delaying further would cause real harm.
The 'Human-in-the-Loop Latency Test' requires measuring how long it actually takes a human to read a model alert and take action — most teams discover it’s measured in ______ or ______ , not seconds.
The 'Decision Forensics' post-mortem on failed projects almost always reveals the original problem statement contained the word 'improve' without a number, a date, or an owner.
The 'Prediction Freshness Clock' starts when the last input data point is collected and ends when the decision must be made — if the window is negative, the project is impossible without streaming.
Which of these is the ultimate litmus test for a truly well-formulated problem?
o: A new team member can read the one-pager once and immediately know whether the project succeeded or failed six months later
The slide deck has a beautiful animated flow diagram
The problem mentions transformers or LLMs
It was presented to the Chief Data Officer

q: The 'Success Theater' anti-pattern occurs when teams celebrate model accuracy milestones while knowing no one will ever use the predictions.

The 'Model Risk vs Business Risk' trade-off says you should accept higher model error if it reduces business risk — for example, in fraud detection, it’s often better to block 100 legitimate transactions than let one $1M fraud through.
The 'One-Page Rule of Pain' states that if you cannot fit the description of the current business pain, its cost, and the proposed remedy on a single page, the problem is not ready for data science.
The 'Reversed Fishbone Diagram' starts from the desired business outcome and works backward to identify which predictions, if perfect, would guarantee the result.
In a maintenance scheduling project, the true north-star metric is not '99% uptime' but 'reduce unplanned downtime cost from $______M to <$______M per year'.
Which framework uses the exact sequence: Opportunity → Desired Outcome → Success Metric → Solution Ideas → Experiments?
Match these brutal stakeholder quotes to the hidden meaning they almost always carry:
left: We’ll get you the data soon
We need something by end of quarter
right: Data access will be a 9-month political battle
No one has calculated actual ROI
They are afraid of measurable commitments
They want a demo, not a real solution

q: Rearrange these words into the question that instantly exposes whether a success metric is real or cosmetic:
What is the output of this code?
o: Project will die in integration phase

q: The 'Three Envelopes' technique is a facilitation trick where participants anonymously write their top 3 fears on envelopes before the workshop to surface blockers early.
The 'Prediction → Intervention → Measurement' loop must be closed within ______ days maximum, otherwise feedback is too slow to improve the model.
The 'Data Graveyard Walk' is a physical tour of old dashboards and models no one uses, conducted during kickoff to remind everyone of past formulation failures.
The 'Calibration Game' forces stakeholders to bet pretend money on whether the current baseline metric will move with or without the project — miscalibration reveals wishful thinking.
The 'No Surprises Clause' in a project charter states that any change to scope, metric, or owner requires a new signed charter within 48 hours or the project pauses.
The 'Economic Validity Threshold' says a project is only worth doing if the expected annual value is at least ______× the fully loaded annual cost.
The 'Decision Archeology' exercise digs up the last 50 times the target decision was made and documents what actually influenced it — 90% of requested features turn out to be irrelevant.
The 'Single Digit Rule' says if your success metric target has more than one significant digit (e.g., 9.73%), you are pretending to have more precision than actually exists.
The 'Model-as-a-Service-Level-Agreement' (Model SLA) template defines not just accuracy but also maximum allowable latency, freshness, and rollback procedure before a single line of code is written.
The 'Intervention Mapping' exercise requires drawing the exact process flow from model score → alert → human action → database update → metric movement, and timing each arrow in minutes or days.
A marketing team wants 'better campaign performance'. The only formulation that survived legal and finance review was:
o: Increase incremental ROAS from 2.8 to ≥4.1 on $180M annual spend with 95% statistical confidence measured via geo-lift tests

q: The 'False Deadline Phenomenon' occurs when stakeholders invent an artificial deadline (e.g., 'board meeting in 6 weeks') because they are afraid to admit the problem is not actually urgent.
Match these advanced facilitation hacks to their real-world effect:
right: Surfaces politically impossible truths safely
Prevents one loud person from dominating priority
Forces quiet stakeholders to speak first
Turns 'good ideas' into someone’s actual homework

q: Rearrange these words into the legendary question that killed more bad data science projects than any other:
What is the output of this code?
o: Humans will ignore the model – threshold too high

q: The 'Champion Test' says a project without a business champion who will personally look bad if it fails is automatically deprioritized.

The 'Label Latency Landmine' explodes when the ground-truth label needed for supervised learning only becomes available ______ after the prediction was needed.
The 'Prediction Consumption Audit' is a half-day exercise where you follow a current report from inbox to trash and count how many people actually read it vs just forward it.
The 'Zero-Based Scoping' method starts every new project by assuming zero features and only adding what is strictly required to move the agreed success metric.

o: Missing it would visibly damage a C-level executive’s personal objectives for the year
It is presented at the annual conference

The 'Metric Ownership Matrix' requires exactly one name in the 'Accountable' column for the primary success metric — committees are not allowed.
The 'Data Debt Clock' displayed on the wall during kickoff shows the cumulative annual cost of the current manual process in real time — it is the single fastest way to create genuine urgency.

o: 'We will know the realistic timeline within 10 working days after we lock the success metric and baseline'

left: This is a vitamin, not a painkiller

Nice-to-have that no one will pay for when budgets tighten

What is the output of this code?
o: Automation ROI obvious even at 70% model accuracy

q: The 'Inverse Conway Maneuver' for data science says you should design the success metric and ownership first, then let the org structure adapt around it — not the other way around.
The 'Three Sacred Questions' that must be answered YES before any modeling starts are: 1. Is there a decision? 2. Does it repeat? 3. Is the ground truth available in time?

The 'Baseline Beatability Score' is calculated as (current human/rule performance – random) divided by (perfect – random) — any project scoring >0.85 is usually not worth automating.

The 'Pain Forwarding Chain' exercise traces who currently receives the complaint or cost when the problem occurs — the person at the end of that chain is your true sponsor.
The 'Last Mile Per Meter' cost calculation proves that getting a prediction from 98% to 99% accurate is often 100× more expensive per percentage point than going from 80% to 90%.

The 'No Number, No Noun' rule bans any success metric that lacks a specific number and a specific business noun (e.g., 'reduce bad debt dollars' is invalid, 'reduce bad debt dollars by ≥$7.3M in FY26' is valid).

To deploy the final model to production

q: Match the success metric type with its appropriate business context:
